On Wed, 2002-08-21 at 11:00, Stevens, Timothy J. (LNG-MBC) wrote:

    >And that JUnit fail after one test fails, so what?  You want all tests to
    >pass so if one fails, find it, fix your code, and go again.
    
    This can be a big problem in large systems that take minutes (or longer) to
    compile and test. 
    

That's a technology problem partly.... get a better development
environment that doesn't need to recompile everything for each small
change.  Run a subset of tests during active development, all tests for
integration & build. Use techniques like Mock Objects to insulate things
being tested, and to speed the tests.

    It's nice to get a complete list of failures so that you
    can attempt to fix as many as possible before having to dive into the build
    process again...

As above, you need tools that support incremental development.  Batch
mode development doesn't cut it anymore, especially not if you are
trying to be Agile (or, better yet, eXtreme).  Also, if you have
multiple failures, they may be ripple effects, although if you are
writing tests properly (which having them all in one method isn't) they
should be independent.

That raises another point:  If you have all your tests in one method (an
extreme case.. even just multiple independent tests in the same method)
you loose the independence,  subsequent tests are sensitive to the
actions of previous ones.
